footer.aboutText: Blue Blocks is a research-led learning ecosystem focused on authentic Montessori and child development.

props.title: THE CHILD, UNDERSTOOD
props.subtitle: Authentic Montessori. The 0–16 Continuum. Education designed for the human spirit.
props.note: At Blue Blocks, we do not view children as empty vessels to be filled. We view them as complete human beings unfolding. While most schools rush to 'teach,' we take the time to observe. By understanding your child's natural development—without interference or pressure—we create the precise environment they need to construct themselves.

props.title: OBSERVATION OVER INSTRUCTION
text: We do not view children as vessels to be filled. We view them as phenomena to be observed.
While others race to finish a curriculum, we apply scientific rigor to the child’s education — not as a series of tests, but as a carefully guided construction of the human being.

A child’s growth cannot be rushed, manufactured, or standardized. It must be understood. Through prepared environments, purposeful routines, and educators trained to observe before they intervene, we help children develop independence, emotional balance, and the confidence to learn deeply — not just for school, but for life.

props.headline: EDUCATION FOR LIFE
props.subText: We do not follow trends. We follow the child.

items.title: The Continuum
items.text: A seamless journey from Infancy (15 Months) to Adolescence (16 Years). No jarring transitions between 'Primary' and 'High School'—just one continuous arc of growth.

items.title: Interdisciplinary Minds
items.text: We don't teach subjects in silos. Biology meets History; Math meets Art. It creates “System Thinkers” for 2050.

items.title: The Prepared Adult
items.text: Our Guides are AMI-Trained observers. Their job is not to 'command' the room, but to remove obstacles so your child can conquer it themselves.

items.title: Scientific Observation
items.text: We don't guess. We observe. Our unique internal research helps us tailor the environment to your child's specific needs, ensuring no one falls through the cracks.

props.title: COMMUNITY QUESTIONS
props.subtitle: Our guides are more than teachers — they are observers, facilitators, and partners in each child’s developmental journey.

items.q: Why do you mix ages in one classroom?
items.a: Because real life is not segregated by birth year. In a mixed-age community, younger children learn by watching, and older children master concepts by teaching. This builds deep social intelligence.

items.q: How do you handle the 'Real World'?
items.a: The 'Real World' rewards those who can think, adapt, and solve problems independently. By prioritizing executive function over rote memorization, we prepare children to lead, not just follow.

items.q: What is your 'Research' approach?
items.a: We believe education should be a science, not an assumption. Our internal observation team studies how children learn best, allowing us to constantly improve our environments. We don't experiment on children; we learn from them.

props.title: A Journey of Observation and Possibility (2009–Present)
paragraphs: Blue Blocks began with a single commitment: understand the child before teaching the child.
For 15 years, we have followed children with care, respect, and scientific precision. What started as one classroom has grown into one of India's few complete 0–18 Montessori environments.
As the children grew, our vision expanded with them. Their questions became prototypes. Their explorations became projects. Their curiosity became innovation.

Our Core Intellectual Framework
Over eight years of systematic observation, Blue Blocks has developed a proprietary pedagogical framework: Developmental Innovation Pedagogy (DIP).
The Core Insight: Innovation is not a single skill taught at age 16. It is the integration of multiple thinking capacities that develop across childhood.

props.title: THE GLOBAL BENCHMARK FOR 2050
props.text: What does the future of education look like? The world is looking to Blue Blocks to find out. We are the first institution to simultaneously hold the trust of the US Department of State, the endorsement of the Association Montessori Internationale, and a premiere invitation from the Nobel Peace Center. From publishing open-science data on Zenodo to establishing India’s first K-12 innovation lab with IIT Hyderabad, we are moving beyond “schooling.” We are defining the global standard for the Zero-Shot Learner.

props.title: Infrastructure for Innovation (0–18): Designed for the Developing Mind.
props.text: At Blue Blocks, we believe architecture is not just a container for learning; it is an active participant in it. Our campus is designed as a “Living Laboratory,” where every angle, texture, and transition is engineered to stimulate specific neural pathways.

items.q: Why is Blue Blocks called a "Research Institute" and not just a school?
items.a: A traditional school focuses on delivering a curriculum to a child. A Research Institute focuses on discovering the child. At Blue Blocks, we operate like a scientific lab—observing, documenting, and refining learning over time.

items.q: Why do you hire PhDs and industry professionals as guides?
items.a: Because Montessori education demands precision, observation, and deep subject knowledge. Our guides bring real-world expertise while remaining faithful to AMI pedagogy.

props.title:
EDUCATION AS AN AID
TO LIFE
paragraphs: At Blue Blocks, we do not group children by age strictly for convenience; we group them by Psychological Phase. Dr. Maria Montessori observed that human beings go through distinct "Planes of Development," each requiring a different environment and a different approach.
We have designed our campus to mirror these natural stages. It is not a school; it is a Living Ecosystem that evolves as your child evolves.

props.title: THE PROGRAMS
props.subtitle: Discover structured learning experiences tailored to each age group — Playgroup, Nursery, Primary, and Secondary.

items.environmentText: A space of movement, language, and order. Here, the child learns to trust themselves and the world. They master the care of self—eating, dressing, and toileting—with dignity
items.parentText: “I never knew my two-year-old could be this calm and capable.”

items.environmentText: The home of the “Work Cycle.” Through Practical Life, Sensorial, and Math materials, the child builds the foundation of concentration and logical thinking.
items.parentText: “My child isn’t just learning to read; they are learning to love learning.”

items.environmentText: The age of “Why?” and “How?”. We offer Cosmic Education—a curriculum where History, Biology, and Math are woven into a grand narrative. Children work in groups, conduct research, and explore the universe.
items.parentText: “They don’t ask for the answers anymore; they ask where to find them.”

items.environmentText: A “School of Experience.” Adolescents engage in real work—managing economies, running businesses, and serving the community. They prepare for adulthood not just academically, but socially and economically.
items.parentText: “My teenager has found a sense of purpose and belonging I didn’t think was possible in high school.”

items.title: Potential Over Percentiles
items.text: We value curiosity, effort, and growth over test scores and comparisons.

props.title: The Psychological Phase
textParts: At this stage, the child is not being taught; they are absorbing. Their primary developmental goal is
. They are driven by an internal directive to master their own movements and bodily functions. We do not interrupt this sacred effort with unnecessary help.

props.title: The Prepared Environment
props.description: This is not a classroom; it is a community. Everything—from the chairs to the sinks—is scaled to the child's size.

items.title: The Conquest of Space
items.text: The child has a biological imperative to move. Our environment is designed for maximum activity—heavy objects to carry, stairs to climb, and washing stands to use. This is not 'burning energy'; it is the coordination of the mind and body.

items.title: The Explosion of Words
items.text: We do not use 'baby talk.' We immerse the child in rich, precise language. We name feelings, objects, and actions. Real conversations happen here, feeding the child's rapidly growing vocabulary.

items.title: Self-Care
items.text: Toilet learning, dressing, and grooming are not chores—they are the curriculum. We use collaborative toileting (no diapers) and clothing that is easy to manage, empowering the child to say, 'I can take care of myself.'

items.title: Social Grace
items.text: Children set the table, serve themselves, and eat from real ceramic plates. It is a ritual of community where they learn patience, sharing, and the joy of eating together.

props.title: Expert Guidance
text: Our AMI-trained guides are observers first. The Anchor of Safety. Our guides provide "psychological safety"—a calm, unhurried presence. They do not entertain the child. They link the child to the activity and then fade into the background, allowing the child to discover their own capability.

items.text: Functional Independence: Eating, dressing, and toileting alone.
Coordinated Movement: Grace and balance.
Explosion of Vocabulary: Expressing needs with words, not tears.
Emotional Regulation: The confidence of self-reliance.

props.title: The Psychological Phase
textParts: The child moves from 'unconscious absorption' to

. The hands become the instruments of the brain. Through touching, moving, and organizing, the child literally constructs their intellect.They are driven by a desire for order, precision, and repetition.

props.title: The Prepared Environment
props.description: A space of order and beauty where materials are scientifically designed to isolate specific concepts.

items.title: Practical Life
items.text: These are not chores; they are the foundation of focus. Washing, polishing, and sweeping build coordination, the will, and the ability to complete a cycle of activity.

items.title: Sensorial
items.text: Refining the senses to perceive differences in the world. Using scientifically designed materials, the child learns to classify dimension, color, shape, and texture.

items.title: Language
items.text: A rich explosion of vocabulary. Through the 'Sandpaper Letters' and 'Moveable Alphabet,' the child discovers that sounds have symbols, leading to an explosion into writing and reading.

items.title: Mathematics
items.text: Making the abstract physically graspable. The child handles the 'Golden Beads' to understand the decimal system concretely before ever seeing a number on a page.

props.title: Expert Guidance
text: The guide does not lecture to the whole class. Instead, they give individual 'presentations,' offering a key to the world, and then leave the child to work freely. This protects the child's concentration from interruption.

items.text: Extended Concentration: The ability to focus deeply.
Love of Order: Internalizing structure
Mathematical Mind: Concrete understanding of the decimal system.
Social Cohesion: Grace and Courtesy.

props.title: The Psychological Phase
textParts: The child has entered the age of the 'Reasoning Mind' and '
.' They are no longer satisfied with 'what' is happening; they demand to know 'why' and 'how.' They are driven to understand the universe and their place within it.

props.title: The Prepared Environment
props.description: The classroom is no longer enough; the library and the outside world become the environment.

items.title: The Great Stories
items.text: Dramatic narratives about the Universe, Life, and Numbers that spark the imagination and provide a framework for all future learning.

items.title: Going Out
items.text: Small groups of students plan and execute field trips entirely on their own to find answers, building real-world logistics skills and independence.

items.title: Collaborative Work
items.text: Children work in groups, navigating social dynamics and learning to debate and agree.

props.title: Expert Guidance
text: They strike the imagination with the 'Great Lessons' to ignite curiosity. They are not the source of all knowledge but the facilitator who points the child toward research resources.

items.text: Moral Agency: Understanding justice and fairness
Research Skills: Independent inquiry.
Big Picture Thinking: Interconnectedness of subjects
Social Collaboration: Working in teams.

props.title: The Psychological Phase
textParts: Adolescence is a 'rebirth.' The student is leaving childhood and entering society. They require
'. —the feeling that they are capable, strong, and their work has value to others. They need to understand economic mechanisms and social structures.

props.title: The Prepared Environment
props.description: A space of order and beauty where materials are scientifically designed to isolate specific concepts.

items.title: Occupation (Work)
items.text: Students run real ventures (e.g., farming, workshops, kitchens). They do not just study biology; they cultivate the soil. They do not just study chemistry; they manage water systems. This is learning through 'doing.'

items.title: Micro-Economy
items.text: The community functions as a small economy. Students create budgets, manage profits, market products, and transact with the outside world. This builds financial literacy and ethical responsibility.

items.title: The History of Humanity
items.text: Adolescents are driven by justice. We study the history of human progress—not as dates to memorize, but as a struggle for survival and civilization—to help them understand where they fit in the story of humanity.

items.title: Residency / Community Life
items.text: Managing the needs of the community—cooking for the group, cleaning, and maintenance. This builds interdependence and the realization that their contribution matters to the group's survival.

props.title: Expert Guidance
text: The adult shifts from 'Teacher' to 'Mentor.' They are experts (scientists, artists, entrepreneurs) who walk alongside the adolescent. They model integrity, work ethic, and intellectual curiosity, treating the student as an emerging adult.

items.text: Economic Capability: A practical understanding of value and money.
Emotional Resilience: Facing real consequences, not artificial punishments.
Social Grace: Navigating complex social hierarchies with empathy.
A Vision of the Future: A clear sense of purpose.

props.title: Blue Blocks Research Institute
props.subtitle: Advancing the Science of Innovation Development in Childhood and Adolescence
props.description: Blue Blocks Research Institute conducts rigorous longitudinal research on how children develop innovative thinking capacities from birth through age 18. Our work bridges developmental psychology, Montessori pedagogy, and innovation science to answer a fundamental question: How does the capacity for original thought emerge, develop, and flourish across childhood?
points: Cognitive architecture of innovation across developmental stages (0–3, 3–6, 6–12, 12–18)
Hand-brain integration and its role in creative problem-solving
Emotional and ethical dimensions of innovative capacity
Material-based learning environments and innovation outcomes
Longitudinal pathways from early exploration to applied innovation

props.title: Our Mission
text: To generate rigorous, replicable knowledge about how innovative thinking develops in children and adolescents, thereby informing educational practice worldwide and establishing evidence-based frameworks for nurturing innovation capacity from the earliest years.
props.callout: We exist to fill a critical gap: while institutions like MIT Media Lab and Stanford d.school advance innovation pedagogy for adults and university students, systematic research on innovation development across the full 0-18 developmental span remains sparse. Blue Blocks Research Institute addresses this gap through sustained, ethical, longitudinal inquiry.

items.title: Ecological Validity
items.text: We study innovation where it naturally occurs—in carefully prepared learning environments where children engage with authentic problems, real materials, and meaningful challenges. Our data emerges from naturalistic observation rather than artificial laboratory conditions.

items.title: Developmental Continuity
items.text: Rather than isolated snapshots, we track the same children over years, documenting how innovation capacities emerge, consolidate, and transform across developmental transitions. This longitudinal approach reveals patterns invisible.

items.title: Ethical Integration
items.text: We hold that innovation without conscience is incomplete. Our research examines not only cognitive and technical dimensions of innovation but also the ethical reasoning and emotional development that shape how children apply their creative capacities.

left.title: Observation Protocols
left.text: Our trained observers employ systematic observation methods adapted for educational research settings. We utilize structured observation cards with pictorial coding systems to ensure reliability across observers with varying literacy levels, following inter-rater reliability protocols.

right.label: Data Collection We gather multi-modal data including:
items: Structured behavioral observations with time-stamped annotations
Photographic and video documentation of innovation processes
Longitudinal case narratives tracking individual developmental trajectories
Emotional arc documentation during problem-solving sequences
Material substitution and adaptive thinking incidents
Social interaction patterns during collaborative innovation

left.title: Retrospective Coding
left.text: Our archival data undergoes rigorous retrospective coding using ethnographic methods, converting eight years of observational records, photographs, and field notes into systematically analyzable datasets.

right.label: Ethical Standards All research activities operate under IRB-compliant protocols. We maintain:
items: Informed consent procedures following international standards
Age-appropriate assent protocols for child participants
Secure data management with strict confidentiality protections
Transparent communication with families regarding research purposes and findings
Clear boundaries between educational practice and research activities

props.title: The Blue Blocks Longitudinal Study
props.subtitle: TThe Blue Blocks Longitudinal Study represents one of the most sustained investigations into innovation development across childhood. Initiated in 2017, the study tracks cohorts of children through their educational journeys, documenting the emergence and evolution of innovative thinking capacities.

The Spark That
Ignited Young
Innovators
content.text: Less than a year ago, our founder Pavan Goyal stepped into a new role — leading the Innovation Programme. His goal was simple yet powerful: unlock the limitlessness of 6–12 year-olds and give them the knowledge to innovate fearlessly.

left.title:
Young Innovators.
Real Impact.
left.text: Nine months later, the results were extraordinary. Children aged 6–11 filed five drone patents — each designed to solve real-world problems.

below.title: The Tribute
below.text: Our students dedicated these innovations to Dr Montessori on her 150th Birth Anniversary, honoring her belief in the potential of every child.

props.title: Meet Our Young Innovators
props.subtitle: A celebration of hands-on learning, discovery, and fearless innovation.

items.text: “These three young men are Ayushman, Sanshray and Dhairya who came up with the idea of a rescue drone to save children who may have fallen into open bore wells. They have been reading/hearing about this unfortunate tragedy that seems to befall us more often than not and decided to not just empathise but aide in providing a solution.”

“Meet Nayonika, Uma, Aditi and Akira- the young girls team that created a drone to deliver essential services to the homes of people. An idea that took shape in the early days of the Covid pandemic, the girls were eager to help out people unable to step out for essentials.”

“The team of Shourya, Anshul, Nihal and Vivaswath came up with a drone design to aide in the detection of covid patients in public places- especially railway stations and bus stops. The drone will do everything from taking the temperature of the suspected case to alert doctors.”

“The team of Shourya, Anshul, Nihal and Vivaswath came up with a drone design to aide in the detection of covid patients in public places- especially railway stations and bus stops. The drone will do everything from taking the temperature of the suspected case to alert doctors.”

“This is the team of Aryan, Hasith and Akshat who took no time at all to come up with the idea of a security drone that will raise an alarm at burglaries, deter perpetrators with pepper spray and also douse fires apart from alerting the police.”

textParts: These children will grow into a world that you and me cannot even begin to imagine. It is high time school education equipped them to not just survive but to thrive in their future. We believe that children need to be ready and relevant as they grow and for that critical thinking skills need to be nurtured. Experiential learning is the way forward, where we develop innovative mindset that will make these children problem solvers as adults. By creating innovation zones we encourage children to think creatively and apply technology in their solutions,” - said Pavan Goyal, Founder and Chief Innovator, Blue Blocks

“We are hoping to revolutionize the thinking and working of the school education system by our approach where outcomes are not realised in the distant future but right here and now. We hope the start we have made will encourage other young innovators and set up the roadmap for the country to follow,” Pavan added.

The Drone Research and Innovation Centre is a first of its kind in the country where research oriented learning is encouraged through observation, exploration, 3d modelling, experimentation, innovating, prototyping, and building. All this come as a natural extension to the work children do in their classroom as part of the Montessori programme right from ages 3 and upwards.

props.title: PROJECT SBB-1:MISSION DASHBOARD
props.subtitle: Validating “First Principles” in Low Earth Orbit.

props.title: Mission Profile
props.description: Project SBB-1 is not a simulation. It is a fully functional CubeSat designed, built, and tested by students under the mentorship of aerospace professionals. The payload was fully flight-qualified and integrated for Low Earth Orbit operations, while validating core educational methodology. This mission represents the culmination of rigorous engineering, academic discipline, and real-world space systems experience.

items.title: The Brain
items.meta: Custom-designed flight computer managing all satellite operations, fault processes, and autonomous decision-making.

items.title: The Senses
items.meta: Integrated sensor suite capturing environmental data across multiple parameters for in-orbit validation.

items.title: The Voice
items.meta: UHF/VHF communication system enabling reliable ground station contact and beacon transmissions.

props.title: Institutional Framework & Compliance
props.description: A mission is only as credible as the institutions that authorize and support it. SBB-1 is embedded within a rigorous regulatory and mentorship ecosystem.

items.title: Authorized by IN-SPACE
items.text: Project SBB-1 operates under official authorization from IN-SPACe.

items.title: Mentored by Industry
items.text: Guidance provided by aerospace partners, ensuring flight-ready standards.

items.title: Data Integrity
items.text: Mission data is processed, validated, and archived for research-grade outputs.

items.title: Conceptualization
items.text: Mission definition, feasibility studies, and initial system architecture design.

items.title: Prototyping
items.text: Breadboard models, component selection, and early integration testing.

items.title: Engineering Model
items.text: Full-scale functional prototype with flight representative components.

items.title: Qualification
items.text: Vibration, thermal vacuum, and EMC testing to space-grade standards.

items.title: Launch Integration
items.text: Final assembly, pre-flight checkout, and integration with PSLV.

items.title: Mission Conclusion
items.text: Payload successfully integrated. Mission concluded due to launch vehicle anomaly (Jan 12, 2026).

props.title: BlueBlocks Space Lab Montessori School for The Space Age
text: The Space Age

At BlueBlocks Montessori, we believe children are not just preparing for the future—they are already shaping it. Our Space Lab is a living expression of that belief: a dedicated environment where adolescents explore the mysteries of the universe through hands-on, real-world scientific inquiry.

Rooted in the Montessori principles of freedom with responsibility, self-directed learning, and cosmic education, the Space Lab empowers students to ask big questions, build meaningful projects, and connect classroom knowledge with the universe beyond.

props.CalloutWrapClass: bg-[#273C75] border-2 border-[#131313] px-7 py-8 sm:px-12 sm:py-10
props.callout: Through the Space Lab and CubeSat program, we aim to nurture a generation of curious, capable, and compassionate explorers—children who not only dream of the stars, but know how to reach them. This is what it means to be a Montessori school for the space age.

props.title: The CubeSat Program
text: The CubeSat program is the culminating experience of the adolescent journey in the Space Lab. In collaboration with Take Me 2 Space, students are now designing and preparing to launch a real satellite into low Earth orbit.

Equipped with sensors such as a gyroscope, accelerometer, magnetometer, radiation sensor, Geiger counter, and spectrometer, the CubeSat will allow students to conduct real research on motion in microgravity, Earth’s magnetic field, space radiation, and atmospheric properties.

What makes this mission truly historic is that it is student-led. Every design decision, experiment, and mission goal reflects the questions and ideas of the children themselves. This is not a simulation—this is real space science, conducted by adolescents who have grown up solving real-world problems through our innovation ecosystem.

props.title: PROJECT SBB-1: STUDENT SATELLITE MISSION
text: Bridging the Gap Between High School and Low Earth Orbit. Space technology is usually reserved for university-level research. At Blue Blocks, we brought it into the 7th-grade classroom.

Project SBB-1 is a fully functional 1U CubeSat, conceptualized and constructed entirely by our 17-member student engineering cohort (ages 12-15). Executed in technical partnership with TakeMe2Space and officially authorized by IN-SPACe, this mission is not a simulation

props.title: “One test of the correctness of educational procedure is the happiness of the child.”
props.subtitle: -Maria Montessori

text: Maria Montessori was a visionary who disabused the traditional methods of education for being too constrictive and non child friendly. In her lifelong work with children first as a pediatric doctor and then as researcher and educator Maria Montessori stumbled up on the secret to not just retaining children’s attention but to successfully divert it for productive work.

Maria Montessori believed that education is an aid for life. Her education philosophy can be summed up in her own words- Never help a child with a task at which he feels he can succeed. She believed the happiness you see in a child is directly proportional to the education he received. She spread her schooling philosophy far and wide to ensure that the first six years of every child lay the best possible foundations for an enriching future.

props.callout: The Montessori philosophy believes that every child is born with a creative mind and a drive to learn. These qualities can be best developed in a free environment. A constructive and proactive methodology, Montessori gives your child the freedom to develop varied interests and the competence needed to get her ready for life.

props.title: Blueblocks Campus
props.description: Blue Blocks campuses are designed as calm, spacious, and purpose-led learning environments where children feel safe to explore, move, and grow with independence. Every space—whether indoors or outdoors—is planned to support self-learning, curiosity, and meaningful social interaction, so children don’t just sit and follow instructions but actively discover, collaborate, and build confidence through hands-on experiences. From well-prepared classroom settings that encourage focus and choice, to open outdoor zones that strengthen coordination, resilience, and problem-solving, the campus becomes an extension of the child’s natural development journey. The overall atmosphere is warm, structured, and child-first—helping every learner develop not only academic foundations, but also real-world skills like responsibility, communication, and self-reliance.

text: Blue Blocks Gachibowli Campus

The Blue Blocks Self-learning Pre-school is a self sufficient spacious learning ground for children. The campus at Gachibowli has four environments that function in two shifts. While three of these environments are dedicated to the Self Interpretive Programme, two environments are dedicated to the Toddler Programme. The outdoors include sand pits, play area with swings, slides and monkey bars.
Blue Blocks Complete School

The Blue Blocks Complete School is a sprawling campus in a one and half acre land at Osman Nagar, Tellapur. The school has two environments one each for Self Interpretive and Elementary Programme. The outdoors include Basketball court, Music Room, Art Room, Amphitheatre and a play area with sand pits and swing.

items.q: Are the admissions done all year round?
items.a: Yes. You can enquire for the same as soon as your child comes of age to fit any of the programmes we offer.

items.q: What will the school tour include?
items.a: Both parents visit the school. Our Parent Coordinator will take the parents through the various spaces in the campus and explain how the Montessori environment supports each child at different stages of development. The tour will be a hands-on experience where parents can see first-hand how the Montessori materials will hone the various senses of the children to help their intellectual and emotional development.

items.q: What is Admission Workshop?
items.a: Following the school tour, all visiting parents attend a group session where they are given details of the Montessori way of learning, the philosophy and pedagogy we follow at Blue Blocks and how it caters to the needs of children. Parents are taken through the journey their child will make at Blue Blocks and how it supports academic and overall development.

items.q: Do you have branches?
items.a: Yes. Our Gachibowli campus has the Toddler and Primary environments while our Osman Nagar campus has Primary, Elementary (Grade 1 to 6) environments and High School (Grade 7 to 10) – Erdkinder Adolescent Program.

items.q: Do you provide transport?
items.a: Yes.

items.q: Do you provide food for children?
items.a: No.

items.q: How do I know the fee structure?
items.a: Once the admission workshop is completed, the school brochure along with the fee structure is shared with the parents.

items.q: How old is the school?
items.a: The school was established in 2009.

items.q: How many campuses do you have?
items.a: We have two campuses — our primary school campus in Gachibowli caters to Play Group and Nursery, while our complete school campus in Osman Nagar, Tellapur runs Nursery, PP1, PP2 and Grades 1 to 10.

items.q: Is Blue Blocks recognised?
items.a: We are recognised by the state government of Telangana.

items.q: Are you affiliated to any board?
items.a: We are affiliated to Cambridge International.

items.q: Are your teachers trained?
items.a: Yes. All our teachers are trained by the Association Montessori International, Netherlands.

items.q: What is the student-teacher ratio?
items.a: In Primary, the teacher-student ratio is 2:20. In Elementary, it is 1:25 with the provision of a trained assistant in both.

items.q: Is it all self-learning or do you teach?
items.a: Montessori teachers act as guides to a child’s independence. They present concepts using specially designed materials, after which the child explores independently through self-correction. Observation helps teachers plan future lessons.

items.q: Is it true that Montessori is all play and no work?
items.a: Maria Montessori believed that play is the work of the child. Through curiosity, children explore their environment and work with materials at their own pace.

items.q: Will the children only learn using materials?
items.a: Montessori moves the child from concrete to abstract learning. Materials engage all senses and form the foundation for complex abstract work later, including work on paper.

items.q: What age do children join this Play Group?
items.a: As soon as your child is able to walk — typically around 1 to 1.5 years of age.

items.q: How long are children in this program?
items.a: They remain in the Play Group until they are 2.5 years of age.

items.q: Do you toilet train the child?
items.a: Yes, we do.

items.q: Do you offer food to the children?
items.a: No.

items.q: Do you have child-friendly infrastructure?
items.a: Yes. All furniture, materials, cutlery and learning tools are child-sized and designed specifically for children.

items.q: What is different from a traditional pre-school?
items.a: Montessori learning is based on children learning through the five senses, at their own pace, using hands-on materials rather than textbooks.

items.q: Are Montessori children able to transition to traditional school?
items.a: Yes. Children can readily join traditional schools in Grade 1 after completing our Primary program.

items.q: What are the timings of the school?
items.a: 8.30 am to 3.30 pm.

items.q: Up to what grade do you offer?
items.a: Our Elementary program is for Grades 1 to 6 for children aged 6 to 12 years.

items.q: Can a non-Montessori child join at Grade 1?
items.a: Yes, subject to observation of the child by the teacher.

items.q: Do you have exams?
items.a: We do not have traditional examinations. Progress is tracked through observations and proficiency-based learning. Cambridge checkpoints may be conducted after ten years of age.

items.q: What is Erd Kinder?
items.a: Erd Kinder is the Montessori adolescent program for ages 12 to 18, based on a farm school concept where children learn academics while managing their own ecosystem.

items.q: How will Cambridge education fit in here?
items.a: Children follow the Cambridge curriculum and textbooks while applying learning to real-life responsibilities and daily work.

items.q: Will it be a residential school?
items.a: It will be semi-residential.

items.q: How are admissions processed?
items.a: Prospective parents register for an Admission Workshop held on Saturdays. All admissions are processed during this workshop.

items.q: What age do you start this programme?
items.a: The program begins at 6 years of age when children move to Grade 1.

items.q: Will it continue to be part of the curriculum in higher classes?
items.a: Yes, innovation remains integrated as children move into higher classes.

items.q: Is it backed by science?
items.a: Yes. Every experiment and model is supported by scientific concepts and theory.

items.q: Do you integrate it with subjects?
items.a: Yes. Innovation activities are closely linked with classroom learning and extend beyond age-level expectations.

items.q: Do children make models?
items.a: Yes. Children build models and prototypes for the concepts they learn.

items.q: Is there a mentor for this work?
items.a: Yes. Dedicated mentors support innovation and drone programs. Mentors include postgraduates in chemistry and aeronautical engineers from IIT, trained as AMI Elementary Assistants.
